newsitem.title: USA: Blueblood Mass. family fighting federal eviction.
newsitem.headline: Blueblood Mass. family fighting federal eviction.

text.p: A blueblood Massachusetts family has barricaded their lavish estate and appealed over the Internet for help to fend off a federal eviction.

John and Rhetta Sweeney refused to meet with U.S. marshals seeking to seize their 14-acre estate in Hamilton, Mass., on behalf of the Federal Deposit and Insurance Corp., which claims the couple owes $1.6 million on a delinquent loan.

"With my background, this is the furthest thing we ever expected," John Sweeney told Reuters by telephone. His family has lived on the estate going back to his great-grandfather, who served in the cabinet of President Theodore Roosevelt and as ambassador to Italy and Russia.
"We're not leaving. There's no negotiation on that," he said.
The U.S. Marshal's office in Boston tried to arrange a meeting Monday and has not yet decided what action to take, Deputy Chief Timothy Bane said.

"We understand these people are not going to leave. We haven't gone up there and asked them to leave yet," he added. "I don't have information that indicates that they are armed or dangerous at this point but we will check that out prior to executing the order."

The Sweeneys have appealed for help over the Internet (www.qui-tam.com) and said they have been contacted by many people, including militia members. "We have been contacted by everybody from church members to patriots. Just the whole spectrum. This is a peaceful, non-violent showing of support," John Sweeney said.
Some volunteers have set up camp on the estate to patrol the property, he said. But there are no weapons on the property, he added.

The dispute with the FDIC goes back to a $1.6 million loan from a local bank. The bank charged that the Sweeneys defaulted on the loan but the family won a court decision awarding it $2.9 million and finding that the bank engaged in unfair and deceptive trade practices.

But a U.S. District Court judge voided the $2.9 million award and ordered the Sweeneys to pay back the loan to the FDIC following the failure of the local bank. When they failed to pay, he ordered an eviction.
"We didn't start this thing but we certainly can't leave," Sweeney said. "What else can you do?"
